item.title: Reading List Picks of 2020
item.description:
First, a confession: there‚Äôs a couple of podcasts hidden in this list of articles and blog posts. But putting that one transgression aside, here‚Äôs some of the best things I read over the last 12 months that either gave me ideas, crystallised my thinking or started to change my mind.

It‚Äôs a longer list than previous years but there‚Äôs plenty in there to fill your browser tabs and bookmarks.

  • Product management & design
  • Digital
  • The Web
  • QAnon
  • Futures
  • UK dance music
  • Just good pieces

Product management & design

Using hypotheses to hold together your learning, thinking, and making

I first came across how to use hypotheses and lines-in-the-sand on the product management course at General Assembly, and I‚Äôve used the technique successfully in a couple of my product teams over the years. John Waterworth posted this on DXW‚Äôs blog earlier this year and I‚Äôve referred back to it a few times since. So I‚Äôm sharing it with you!

Read Using hypotheses to hold together your learning, thinking, and making.

Calm Product Manager / Stressed Product Manager

There is no doubt that this year has been hard for everyone. There was a moment before the pandemic hit where I was a little stressed out, and I came across this post. It helped me to notice the behaviours I was exhibiting and how those would impact our work, which helped me shift gear and slow down.

Read Calm Product Manager / Stressed Product Manager.

It takes two

A cracking post from Jukesie that illustrates the nuances between product managers and delivery managers on multidisciplinary teams. Though the roles overlap, there‚Äôs a clear distinction between each role‚Äôs purpose ‚Äì and when you work together, as a team, excellent things occur. I‚Äôve forwarded it to several people who were worried about stepping on the toes of their colleagues.

Read It takes two.

Product Work Beyond Product-Market Fit

When I joined GOV.UK Pay and started reviewing the roadmap with the team leads, usually preceding quarterly planning, I found it hard to have discussions around what to prioritise. Unlike others who‚Äôd been on the team longer, I didn‚Äôt have a detailed knowledge of recent history and couldn‚Äôt easily discuss the work within the product‚Äôs strategic context. So I used this article to categorise our work into four groups, helping us decide what to do now, next and later ‚Äì and what not to do. I find it‚Äôs now much easier to talk about the value of each piece of work relative to all the others.

Read Product Work Beyond Product-Market Fit.

The Boring Designer

Someone shared this with me after reading Boring magic, and it describes the design approach I think we strive for working on government digital services. It‚Äôs not that you can‚Äôt add delighters to your product or service, but those delighters are inherently utilitarian. And when it comes to grand visions: ‚ÄòIf there‚Äôs The Big Idea, the boring designer is fantastic at finding a reasonable step one instead of making The Big Idea the starting line.‚Äô

Read The Boring Designer.

Digital

Russell Davies‚Äôs strategy advice

Over the last 18 months, I‚Äôve been focused on learning more about strategy. It‚Äôs really easy to tie yourself in knots with strategy, it‚Äôs such a fluffy concept. But this post by Anna Shipman helped me realise a few things: first, that it pays to be clear, about what you‚Äôre not going to do in addition to what you will do; second, that no one person should do it on their own; and third, that if you‚Äôre a product manager you‚Äôre probably ‚Äòdoing strategy‚Äô already, you just hadn‚Äôt realised it.

Read Russell Davies‚Äôs strategy advice.

Delivering digital service: this much I have learned

It can be tempting to think that, because it moves so fast, working in digital needs new methods, a new focus, or something else to help us deliver better outcomes. So it‚Äôs comforting to read this post on what made things work over the last 20 years. If you ever find yourself saying ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs fix this basics‚Äô in your organisation, I reckon this post is a lightweight owner‚Äôs manual for that.

Read Delivering digital service: this much I have learned.

Multi-hyphenates

You won‚Äôt always have access to the specialists you need, and some times you have to fill gaps briefly. That‚Äôs where it comes in handy to be a generalist or, as Jukesie calls it, a multi-hyphenate. Not a jack-of-all-trades, but not far off.

Read Multi-hyphenates.

Dave Rogers on trust and culture in technology organisations

Another thing I spent all year thinking about was trust and culture in technology organisations. How do you get everyone pushing the same boulder? What makes it feel like a one-in-a-lifetime experience, not a chore? How can we do that in the Internet Age, leaving industrialist methods behind? Dave sums up the qualities of a high-performing, empowered organisation excellently.

Read Mistrust makes technology toxic and Culture eats technology for breakfast.

How to debug distributed teamwork, as suggested by new research

Everyone who previously worked in an office has been thinking about remote, distributed and hybrid working this year. I‚Äôve always been keen on a more flexible working arrangement so spent time researching a range of approaches with my delivery manager, so that we could experiment with our ways of working on GOV.UK Pay. This framework from Leisa Reichelt at Atlassian is the step we‚Äôll take next, to consider our colleagues work‚Äìlife balance from a human-centred perspective, designing our working arrangements around needs.

Read How to debug distributed teamwork, as suggested by new research.

The Web

Webwaste

Of everything I‚Äôm sharing this year, this piece had the biggest impact for me personally. Though I knew about the problem of sustainability in digital, Gerry McGovern made it palpable through the everyday examples in this article. It inspired me to make this website less carbon-intensive.

Read Webwaste.

Small b blogging

This post by Tom Critchlow is a lovely piece on the purpose of personal blogs, against a backdrop of content marketing and advertorials. Not quite microblogging and not quite long reads, small-b blogging is all about the serendipity of personal networks. Some times ‚Äòpersonalisation‚Äô is hand-crafted, not algorithmically ordained.

Read Small b blogging.

Why does it suddenly feel like 1999 on the internet?

‚ÄòBefore social media soured us and made us aloof and dismissive, we used to take the internet‚Äôs promise of serendipitous connection more seriously.‚Äô In a similar vein to Tom‚Äôs post, this piece in MIT Technology Review points to the resurgence of the Internet‚Äôs original phenomenon: feeling part of one giant community.

Read Why does it suddenly feel like 1999 on the internet?.

Hard to Believe

This is a post about epistemology and how the Web is morphing the definitions of knowledge and information. If you use Google or ask questions to a voice assistant, it‚Äôs definitely worth a read. Very relevant for the next section too.

Read Hard to Believe.

QAnon

Having grown up on the Web in the early 2000s, I‚Äôm no stranger to conspiracy theories and mis- or disinformation. Every now and then, surfing around corners of the Web, you‚Äôd come across something that felt a bit fishy. You developed a sense for which sources to trust and which to ignore.

QAnon represents a mainstream cultural shift, I think, a signifier that normal people are now extremely online, not just nerdy adolescent boys in their bedrooms. It‚Äôs obvious when you say it out loud but I hadn‚Äôt seen it before.

The following podcasts and blog posts sum it up evocatively.

  • First, listen to the Rabbit Hole podcast episodes, Where We Go One and We Go All
  • then read What ARGs Can Teach Us About QAnon by Adrian Hon
  • Adrian‚Äôs brother Dan also wrote about it in s08e18: QAnon looks like an alternate reality game
  • The Apophenic Machine by Molly Sauter zooms out from ARGs, presenting QAnon in the context of electronic communications, and
  • finish on the Reply All podcast, Country of Liars, which pulls back the curtain.

Futures

The Necessity of a Boring Revolution

In my head, the original vision for Government as a Platform was a strategic design to bring about a boring revolution, setting some of the conditions required for regulatory innovation. Digital government is still on that path, but some of the near-term tactics have changed in the last two years (in the UK at least). Recent moves by the UK, the US and the European Commission to regulate Big Tech shows that regulators may seek to be more nimble and agile in the future too. This piece by the inimitable Indy Johar should helps ignite creative thought in the government digital space.

Read The Necessity of a Boring Revolution.

Making Kin with the Machines

‚ÄòWhat if we treated AI as equals, like other human beings, not as tools or, worse, slaves to their creators?‚Äô That‚Äôs the premise to this paper, which is a wonderful provocation. It‚Äôs a really important consideration too, when you consider how many of our decisions we‚Äôre asking machine sentience to make for us. If algorithmic bias were a human judge, they‚Äôd be thrown out of court (you‚Äôd hope).

Read Making Kin with the Machines.

Rebooting ‚Äòprogressive‚Äô politics in the digital age

Directly related to the two pieces above, this article talks about the inherent relation between software and politics if we‚Äôre to make data a key part of policy-making.

Read Rebooting ‚Äòprogressive‚Äô politics in the digital age.

The Coronavirus Is Rewriting Our Imaginations

‚ÄòIndividualism is giving way to collectivism‚Äô is how I‚Äôd summarise this article. In the Great Cyclical Nature of All Things, the neoliberal core of the last 40 years is becoming more apparent to more people, and a politico-social shift is occurring. People are starting to see the routes forward to a new world view.

Read The Coronavirus Is Rewriting Our Imaginations.

It doesn‚Äôt have to be like this

Taking in much of the above and considering the next step forward in the UK, Jon Alexander considers three shifts that need to occur in how government (small ‚Äòg‚Äô) underwrites the social contract for the post-coronavirus future.

Read It doesn‚Äôt have to be like this.

UK dance music

An Audience with Andrew Weatherall

The legendary acid house DJ and music producer, who sadly passed away this year, answers questions from the public. Aside from the unequivocal classification of Facebook as unnecessary bullshit, he also touches on how humanity hasn‚Äôt changed in 100,000 years, it‚Äôs just our technology that has.

Read An Audience with Andrew Weatherall.

Structural racism in UK dance music

Read these pieces and make up your own mind on what needs to happen next.

  • How much of UK dance music history is real?
  • STRUCTURAL RACISM IN UK DANCE MUSIC: TIME FOR ACTION
  • Black Sky Thinking

Just good pieces

Working-class people don‚Äôt need to ‚Äúbreak into the elite‚Äù ‚Äì we need to change it

I‚Äôm still processing some of my thoughts and feelings after reading Nathalie Olah‚Äôs Steal as much as you can, but I‚Äôm sharing this for anyone else from a working class background. It touches on the themes of her book, which I hope inspire you.

Read Working-class people don‚Äôt need to ‚Äúbreak into the elite‚Äù ‚Äì we need to change it.

Mission Control: A History of the Urban Dashboard

There has been much talk of dashboards this year, the instrumenting of control. This piece covers consoles, cockpits, dashboards and, my favourite, Project Cybersyn, in its short history of evidence-informed analysis.

Read Mission Control: A History of the Urban Dashboard.

The Battle of Los Angeles

After reading this, I realised how much I‚Äôd learned about colonialism and structural racism from reading up on Rage lyrics as a teenager. Much more to learn, of course, but Battle really was a primer.

Read The Battle of Los Angeles.

item.title: Going dark
item.description:
A few pieces I‚Äôve written during NaBloPoMo 2020 have been fun to write. Others were more strained.

I‚Äôm not sure any of them made a good point. I‚Äôd like to improve my writing, and committing to writing weeknotes means I can often lose my steam.

Also, good writing starts with good reading, and my note-taking habits have changed recently.

By reducing the amount of things I write and publish, I should hopefully give more space for thoughts to percolate, develop and crystallise.

So I‚Äôm going dark.

See you later.

There is a clear overproduction of things (intangible and tangible) that have been created uncritically, unquestioningly, without needing to meet any type of standard other than existing. New output is produced everyday due to the accessibility of tools for creation‚Ä¶ We have grown accustomed to shutting off our critical thinking faculties‚Ä¶ Critical thinking in action by consumers and creators leads to output being respected and valued accurately, which pushes culture forward towards the infinite cultural mindset.1

  1. https://maekan.com/article/the-modern-creators-paradigm¬†↩

item.title: Many of the things people worry about are not really worth worrying about
item.description:
A few years ago I worked with film-maker Tomas Leach on a book for his documentary, In No Great Hurry1. The documentary is about the late Saul Leiter, a photographer who made the mundane magnificent.

His style is unique. He takes pictures of boring things: condensation on a window, red umbrellas, taxi cars. Moments of urban life we‚Äôd all find commonplace. His composition made these scenes hard to unpick, a tad abstract. It would take a few moments to work out what you were seeing.

That was part of the allure. Shooting in the 1950s and 1960s, he was also an early pioneer of colour photography, which would equally draw the eye after a century of black and white photography.

Saul‚Äôs photography was boring magic, without a doubt.

His style causes us to slow down, to take in more of our surroundings. Inspect the ordinary for shades of delight.

Often I wonder whether we should be doing that more. In many aspects of life. We needn‚Äôt always be in motion, always moving on to the next thing.

What if now is just enough?

I‚Äôm a person who likes to postpone things. I see no reason for being in a rush. When you consider many of the things that people treat very seriously, you realise that they don‚Äôt deserve to be treated that seriously. And many of the things people worry about are not really worth worrying about. If I didn‚Äôt do anything more than my little book, would that have been enough? ‚Äì Saul Leiter

  1. Nothing came of the project, unfortunately. I experienced a severe bout of depression and couldn‚Äôt carry on. I really wish I had.¬†↩

item.title: Silly ideas
item.description:
Over the years I‚Äôve kept these silly ideas for apps and gadgets in a note on my phone.

Most of them are really silly, bordering on pointless. For a while that was a particular focus, pointlessness.

An app for recording how quickly your toenails grow.

An app that utilises AI to compute when your urine will start smelling of asparagus.

IoT-controlled wind chime, allowing you to turn it off when it‚Äôs annoying. It comes with a mini fan for when there‚Äôs no wind.

But there‚Äôs one I really want to build: Deliveroulette.

Enter your post code, a time to be fed and your budget, anything from ¬£20 to ¬£50. A bot will randomly select a restaurant, pick some things off the menu and place the order for you. A little while later the doorbell rings.

A surprise dinner!

It‚Äôs better than TimeHop for toenails, anyway.

item.title: Google Search is the fast-food restaurant of knowledge
item.description:
Getting hold of knowledge is harder than we think. Most of what a search engine returns is information, and it‚Äôs our job to piece it together and generate knowledge: facts and things we know.

Google is really, really good at giving you information and lots of it. But, on average, how many of us click more than one link from the first five results? How many of us honestly take snippets from multiple sources and reason our own judgements?

In making it easy to get to information, Google has made itself a primary source of knowledge nutrition. But it is, at best, a fast-food restaurant: highly operationalised basic sustenance.

And it‚Äôs bad to rely on these behemoths. Most people don‚Äôt eat only at McDonald‚Äôs. So why feed our brains, our arguments, our faculties of reasoning, on a similar giant?

When I was product manager for GOV.UK‚Äôs site search engine, I set the team a project to learn more about how search engines work. For one week, they had to change their main search provider from Google to something else. Bing, Baidu, Dogpile, DuckDuckGo, Ecosia, or anything else. At the end of the week we talked about what was harder or took more effort, the features they missed from Google, and whether they wanted to carry on using that provider.

Some people said yes, some people switched back to Google, but all of us learned how to find things in a different way. We had to actively engage our epistemological faculties and work with a corpus.

Since then I‚Äôve been using DuckDuckGo every day because I like the way it works. It reminds me of the early web, around 2002, a time when AltaVista and AskJeeves were big names in web search. Back then you‚Äôd fall into rabbit holes, starting on one page and diving through links, resurfacing to open up another, related rabbit hole by searching again. We built up information this way. You‚Äôd be delighted at what you found sometimes, learning something you hadn‚Äôt expected to find.

That pursuit of digging into a topic and building up your own knowledge base is losing ground to instant gratification. Voice assistants, in taking away the hassle of having to read, could take it away all together.

How might we make our own information-gathering Michelin starred? What skills do we need to refresh or relearn?

These habits of mind ‚Äì how we weigh up information and find truth ‚Äì are helpful in many places. Not only in our work projects but also, most critically, at the ballot box.

‚ÄúWe do not and cannot gain knowledge by passively recording reality in declarative sentences, as if we were baskets ready to be filled; instead, we must handle it interactively.‚Äù ‚Äì Luciano Floridi

Some things that inspired this post: Matt Webb‚Äôs 15 rules for blogging; Motherboard‚Äôs piece on popular culture as an information conduit and nuclear energy influencer Isodope; and The New Atlantis on whether search engines make us gullible.

item.title: Why I write weeknotes
item.description:
Each weekend I spend around 2 hours writing about what I did in the ~38 hours I spent at work that week. Why? Good question. Here‚Äôs a few reasons why spending more time than is necessary writing about work is a good thing.

It helps me think

Writing is a reflective practice. By going over what you did and writing about it, considering the objectives you were trying to meet and whether you got there, you actively think through and reflect on your work. You spot areas for improvement or things you forgot to do. Whereas otherwise you might canter through working life unsure of what worked or what didn‚Äôt, weeknoting makes you mindful of what you‚Äôre doing and why.

It makes professional development easier

Each month I chat with my line manager about what I‚Äôve been doing at work and how I‚Äôm progressing against my professional objectives. Because those conversations are based around what I‚Äôve been doing ‚Äì and we do a lot ‚Äì having it written down is super helpful.

It builds networks

Some times I‚Äôve written about a problem we‚Äôve been having, and other people have got in touch to say they have that problem too. Then we chat about it and think of a way forward, or they tell me how they‚Äôve solved it before. This kind of networking, which happens outside your immediate work bubble, is spontaneous but just as useful as established, near networks at work.

It builds social mobility

I come from a working class background and was the first person in my family to go to university. That means I didn‚Äôt learn about office culture, its politics and how to get ahead as a white-collar worker until I started working in an office. My dad is a builder, not a CEO or politician, so tales at the dinner table didn‚Äôt prepare me for where I work.

But I‚Äôve found that by reading through other people‚Äôs weeknotes I can get a sense for how things are done. By writing my own notes and putting them out in the open, I have to actively walk the walk as much as talk the talk. By building credibility and showing my working in a sector renowned for cronyism, I‚Äôm hopefully proving my worth to prospective employers.

It‚Äôs a tiny, tiny public service

In a way, the taxpayer is funding everything I do at work, so they probably have a right to know what I‚Äôm doing. And one day someone might fill my place and want to know what I got up to. Weeknotes are searchable records of (almost) everything I did at work, providing a history for those who come after me. Blogging and working in the open as a public servant helps to open up government, form a dialogue with our audience, and share what we‚Äôve learnt.

On the scale of public services they‚Äôre not that important, obviously. They‚Äôre not universal healthcare. But if one other person saves time solving a problem using my notes, that‚Äôs a good thing.

Further reading

  • Weeknotes: personal, public logs in the tradition of early blogging
  • A pre-history of weeknotes, plus why I write them and perhaps why you should too
  • The why of weeknotes by Jukesie
  • The why of weeknotes by Sam Villis
  • Tips for writing good weeknotes

item.title: This website is killing the planet
item.description:
For a while I‚Äôve been intending to make my website more sustainable, but I succumbed, as I often do, to the human trait of sloth. But this morning after reading Gerry McGovern‚Äôs post on webwaste, I thought I‚Äôd procrastinated long enough.

So I ran a web page performance test and got some grim results: my website takes over a minute to load on a Moto G4 on using 3G data networks. It‚Äôs just as bad using a desktop PC in Nottingham on 1.5Mbps DSL. My website is bloated with large images and a bunch of JavaScript, which means it‚Äôs eating up lots of energy transmitting those bits and bytes.

But how much energy? I used the Website Carbon Calculator to find out. It turns out that

  • 6.90g of CO2 is produced every time someone visits the homepage
  • it emits the amount of carbon that 4 trees absorb in a year, and
  • it uses enough electricity to drive an electric car 1,116km

Eugh. That‚Äôs disgusting. For each year my website has been online, I should have planted 4 trees just for the homepage alone. But, instead, my laziness has filled the atmosphere with more and more carbon.

I have to do something, this has gone on long enough, so I‚Äôm committing to some actions.

  1. I‚Äôll move my site to a web hosting provider using renewable energy, one that‚Äôs listed on the Green Web Foundation‚Äôs directory. ‚úÖ
  2. I‚Äôll compress and optimise the images on my site using ImageOptim. ‚úÖ
  3. I‚Äôll get rid of my energy-guzzling site theme until I can introduce one that‚Äôs lightweight and accessible. ‚úÖ
  4. Going forward, my website will enshrine the principles of the Sustainable Web Manifesto. üìù
  5. I‚Äôll pay for some trees to be planted that‚Äôll reduce the impact of my website‚Äôs carbon footprint going forward. ‚úÖ View the certificate üìú

To show my commitment to being a good web citizen, I‚Äôll add the Website Carbon Badge to all pages ‚úÖ and the Green Web Foundation‚Äôs renewable hosting badge ‚úÖ. Once I‚Äôve improved things, I‚Äôll add a carbon.txt ‚úÖ.

One day I‚Äôll actually get around to building a solar-powered battery bank and run my site off my home connection, but until then I‚Äôm taking small steps to remove, minimise and clean-up my presence on the web.

What‚Äôs the carbon footprint of your website? What steps will you take to reduce it?

Further reading

  • Webwaste
  • The bullshit web
  • 3 steps to creating zero carbon websites
  • How to build a low-tech website
  • Greening Internet governance: environmental sustainability and digital transformation

It has been great to read everyone‚Äôs responses to this post, even those questioning the merit of reducing carbon emissions on a personal website. Here‚Äôs action others have decided to take on their own websites.

item.title: Blogging and working in the open
item.description:
This is a talk I gave to the GDS product management community a year ago. It‚Äôs mostly aimed at other people working in digital transformation of government, but actually I think everyone should blog a bit.

There‚Äôs lots of ways of working in the open, blogging is just one of them.

So what is the point of blogging?

First we should define what a blog is. The noun ‚Äòblog‚Äô means a regularly updated website or web page, typically one run by an individual or small group, that is written in an informal or conversational style.

Blogs have been a part of the Web since the 1990s when web publishing tools were made easier-to-use for non-technical folk. They‚Äôve always tended to be in a diary style, allowing people to talk about what they do, their interests and anything they please.

But what‚Äôs the point of blogging in government?

Blogging helps to

  • open up government
  • form a dialogue with our audience
  • share what we‚Äôve learnt

It‚Äôs really all about starting conversations and sharing knowledge. The audience might be fellow service creators or it might be end users.

But it‚Äôs worthwhile taking this a step further. Blogging is all about working in the open. Working in the open causes you to be honest about your work and makes it easier to collaborate with smart communities of peers.

I‚Äôll expand on that‚Ä¶

What‚Äôs the point of being open?

The Government Transformation Strategy says that ‚Äòa culture of open, digitally enabled policy making and service delivery is critical to our future success.‚Äô It‚Äôs written into our values as an organisation too: ‚ÄòMake things open, it makes things better.‚Äô

Being open is about the importance of working across organisational boundaries to make things better for users.

If someone in Department A talks about a particular problem and someone in Department B says they‚Äôve encountered the same thing, they‚Äôre likely to ignore the boundaries and differences between their departments and explore the problem together.

The shared goal is making things better for users and working in the open helps facilitate that.

So, more formally, what are the goals of openness?

And these don‚Äôt just cover blogging, they can be attributed to our day-to-day practice too.

The goals of openness

These come from Open Matt.

Participation: it‚Äôs rocket-fuel for smart collaboration. Speaking outside of your organisational box can attract other people, get conversations started and accelerate collaboration. (Joined-up working, yeah?)

Agility: speed, flexibility, getting shit done. When you work in the open, you‚Äôre more likely to check what you‚Äôre saying before putting it out there. It encourages a better, more accountable working practice, as well as working out how to build the right thing.

Momentum: communities want to push boulders that are already moving. Simply put, working in the open is cheap PR. People love to get involved in exciting projects headed in the right direction. One of my favourite stories is how Neil Williams got offered a job at GDS because he blogged so enthusiastically about a single government website, and Tom Loosemore happened to spot it. But you see this with the Local Digital Coalition too. Teams in previously under-the-radar councils becoming visibly active in improving their authority‚Äôs ways of working.

Testing and rapid prototyping: refining as we go. Working in the open creates better feedback and testing loops, and the history of changes is documented. You have the opportunity to welcome a more diverse set of voices to comment on your work, which is always a good thing.

Leverage: getting greater bang from our limited resources. And again, blogging is really cheap PR. I‚Äôve personally made a ton of good connections I didn‚Äôt expect simply by talking about what I‚Äôve done. Don‚Äôt worry about making things too polished though, raw honesty (or slightly processed honesty ‚Äì runny honey) is some of the secret sauce to making it work. (That means you can talk about failure as well as success.)

So why blog about our work?

Blogging is not about thought leadership or public performance, it‚Äôs about actively feeding the conversation around agile, user-centred transformation.

By putting our experiences out there and talking about the new challenges we‚Äôre facing, people can empathise or respond, developing the transformation project we‚Äôre all a part of.

And we should be more open to talking about failure too, or announcing when things didn‚Äôt go to plan. Not to call ourselves out but help others later down the line.

This is an excellent quote from Ellie Craven who used to be the PM on GOV.UK Registers.

‚ÄòThe more we obscure how we work, and why it‚Äôs valuable, the harder we‚Äôll find it to gain broad organisational support for the next project, and the one after that.‚Äô

Talking about our work helps us better describe it and its value across government. It also gives you a chance to show your working without that person needing to attend a talk or Show & Tell.

And then she goes one better‚Ä¶

‚ÄòWe should do the hard work to make this simpler for those who come after us.‚Äô

That‚Äôs my emphasis, but talking about our work now helps people who might one day step into our shoes.

So going back to what I said before, blogging helps to

  • open up government
  • form a dialogue with our audience
  • share what we‚Äôve learnt

Some principles

Some principles (for civil servants) then.

The Civil Service Code underpins everything. Stick by that.

But the first real rule, don‚Äôt be a dick.

Try not to be the person to say the wrong thing or inadvertently give away a ministerial plan or cause offence to a team member. None of that is good, but you can mitigate it by asking a second pair of eyes to look over your work.

Ask someone before mentioning them, they might be staying away from the ‚Äòspotlight‚Äô. One of my colleagues doesn‚Äôt use social media, for example, and wants to stay away from it, so I only ever referred to them as ‚Äòour delivery manager‚Äô.

Spoilers suck, so avoid telling another team‚Äôs story. They might be doing great things but try not to build too much of a picture if you must mention it. They should have the right to cause a splash.

How can I start blogging?

Hopefully that‚Äôs done enough to convince you to get started. So here‚Äôs a few tips to get going.

Add a ‚ÄòBlog‚Äô column to your kanban board. It‚Äôll help you consider which pieces of work are worth sharing and talking about. You might even build up a few stories per sprint to talk about. Break it down into smaller chunks, it‚Äôs much easier.

If you want to start small and maybe try something more personal, weeknotes are a great way to get going. Weeknotes are personal reflections on your working week to learn from what you‚Äôve done and improve your practice from week to week. You simply write about what you‚Äôve done and how you feel about how it went.

There‚Äôs an excellent community on the #weeknotes hashtag on Twitter who can give you ideas, but you can also just ask for help. They‚Äôre super friendly.

It‚Äôs worth saying that blogging isn‚Äôt an easy thing to start, you‚Äôll probably get ‚Äòthe fear‚Äô about receiving criticism on your work or thoughts. But that‚Äôs fine, my advice is to just dive in and have a go. Usually your fears don‚Äôt match reality, and there‚Äôs an amazing community there to comment and help if you‚Äôre struggling anyway.

And if you‚Äôre worried about writing about work in the public domain, don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs OK. You have permission. People high up at director level are doing it, just take a look at what Matt Edgar, Rox Heaton and Ross Ferguson are doing.

You don‚Äôt need any money to get started, really, you can spin up a blog in minutes using platforms like Wordpress and Medium. It‚Äôs a quick way to test out the practice and see if it‚Äôs right for you.

If you‚Äôd like to create your own website, static site generators like Jekyll and Hugo are low-tech ways to get started. You might have heard of GitHub Pages which runs on Jekyll. You simply feed it some Markdown files and it builds a website for you. GitHub Pages is free too, and it‚Äôs a good way to become more familiar with Git in general.

And you needn‚Äôt worry about having to promote your blog posts either. Services like Missinglettr, Zapier and Quuu Promote will syndicate your blog posts on social media automatically, helping your posts to get a greater reach.

You may become a self-facilitating media node. That‚Äôs fine. The goal is to share knowledge and passion and get more people involved in agile, user-centred transformation.

A note on passion

At the end of the talk, I asked members of the audience to raise their hand if they wanted to work at GDS after reading one of its blog posts. 75 per cent of people put their hand up.

Thank you to Matt Jukes, Amanda Smith, Giles Turnbull, Neil Williams, Dan Barrett, Ellie Craven, Sam Villis, Jonathan Kerr and the #weeknotes folks, stalwarts of the blogging and working in the open community who inspired this.

Further reading

  • Agile communication tips
  • On writing
  • The importance of being open
  • Why I write weeknotes
  • Let‚Äôs write more blog posts
  • Small b blogging
  • Blogging is great
  • Tips for writing good weeknotes

item.title: Reading List Picks of 2019
item.description:
Here‚Äôs a bunch of articles and blog posts that got me thinking about digital government, product management, design thinking, the World Wide Web and data this year. There‚Äôs also a couple of nice stories I enjoyed thrown in. Oh, and some stuff about attention too, because this list is full of useful distractions.

I‚Äôve not included anything about privacy, which I should have, but I think that probably deserves its own post.

Digital government

Just enough Internet: Why public service Internet should be a model of restraint

Heavyweight thinking on good, responsible technology in public service from Rachel Coldicutt, which has been this year‚Äôs hot topic alongside privacy. Rachel‚Äôs piece does well to bring together thinking from across the public service space, including sessions from MozFest 2018, viewing it through a lens of sustainability.

Read Just enough Internet: Why public service Internet should be a model of restraint.

There is no such thing as the government

This was posted in 2010, around the time Martha Lane Fox‚Äôs report on Directgov was published, leading to the creation of Government Digital Service and GOV.UK. In it Stefan Czerniawski talks about how the dream for joined-up government services has been around for years, and it‚Äôs a key historical text for anyone working in the current era of transformation1. (There‚Äôs bonus archived blog posts from Tom, Neil, and Jukesie.)

Read There is no such thing as the government.

The problem with the service lifecycle

The service design lifecycle in government has four stages: discovery, alpha, beta, live. It‚Äôs an agile technique from the world of software development, and its aim is to help teams and organisations create new things while reducing waste. But it‚Äôs a linear strategy with a resolute end, it doesn‚Äôt set you up for what‚Äôs next. Sanjay put forward the idea of the lifecycle as a spiral, which I really like as it helps you think about step-changes. You might have digitised a bunch of paper forms, but how might you discover the bigger problem to solve?

Read The problem with the service lifecycle.

Data-sharing in government: why it‚Äôs time for a new approach

If bits of government start using more data to design and deliver things, what will people think about government and will they trust it? This is one of many pieces Richard has written in his software is politics genre, but it‚Äôs a good one for considering how the social contract plays into trust models and data re-use. Essentially: there should be clear lines of accountability and responsibility for citizens to have recourse.

Read Data-sharing in government: why it‚Äôs time for a new approach.

Product management & design thinking

Right question, wrong answer: agile stakeholder management

Most product teams will know about HiPPOs ‚Äì the highest paid person in the organisation ‚Äì and their opinions. Sometimes senior people will ask why a team hasn‚Äôt produced a particular output, and Matt puts forward a helpful mindset for breaking that down. It‚Äôs easy to get dismayed or irked in those situations but this piece sets a principled approach.

Read Right question, wrong answer: agile stakeholder management.

Resources for applying a systems lens to your work

I spent a lot of time looking at the bigger picture in work this year and came across this post in the summer. It has a a bunch of great resources for how to address root causes, not symptoms of problems ‚Äì systems-thinking. Even reading the first book on the list, Dan Hill‚Äôs Dark Matter and Trojan Horses, changed the way I work. Make your way through the list, it‚Äôs great. Shout-out to Aly (and Will, of course).

Read Resources for applying a systems lens to your work.

A New Social Contract

The first post in a four-part series on redesigning democracy from Alastair Parvin. He‚Äôs done incredibly well to set the problems and proposed solutions within their context, making it all relatable. An expert use of storytelling and systems-thinking to propose new futures, with a nod to government as a platform.

Read A New Social Contract.

Why you should stop using product roadmaps and try GIST planning

A decent framework from Itamar Gilad that wraps in Lean Startup methods, OKRs, and a pipeline for testing ideas, all sat beneath the organisation‚Äôs shared goals and strategy. I tried it out on the Search team and we made some good progress. A good way to avoid the agile build trap, do more prototyping, and empower product teams to deliver outcomes.

Read Why you should stop using product roadmaps and try GIST planning.

I Read About ‚ÄúDesign For Trust‚Äù So You Don‚Äôt Have To

Does what it says on the tin. A compendium of links to and a summary of many ‚Äòdesign for trust‚Äô posts from across the Web. (It‚Äôs worth reading all the content the author draws on though!)

Read I Read About ‚ÄúDesign For Trust‚Äù So You Don‚Äôt Have To.

The world is distracted

The Machine Stops

Either peak smartphone isn‚Äôt far off or we‚Äôve reached it already. The late neurologist Oliver Sacks writes about the disappearence of old civilities, where people have replaced talking to their neighbours with talking to their phones. But there‚Äôs hope in this piece too, that people will realise the need to sustain the richness of human cultures. And since more of us are putting our phones down, I‚Äôm hopeful too.

Read The Machine Stops.

The attention economy

Owen Williams puts forward the idea that most products are competing for the space in front of your eyeballs. Attention is now a commodity as much as technology, and the only limit is the population and the number of waking hours.

Read The attention economy.

The Case for Doing Nothing

Niksen is the Dutch concept of embracing boredom to stop ourselves being so busy. It‚Äôs a bit like mindfulness, only you don‚Äôt need to pay Headspace a subscription fee to learn how to do it. This piece makes the case for doing nothing with purpose.

Read The Case for Doing Nothing.

The Web and data

30 years on, what‚Äôs next #ForTheWeb?

The World Wide Web is 30 years old, so I couldn‚Äôt not include this. Since you‚Äôre using the Web, please read it!

Read 30 years on, what‚Äôs next #ForTheWeb?.

The Internet‚Äôs Back-to-the-Land Movement

Following on from the piece by Lowtech magazine in last year‚Äôs picks, this piece by Becca Abbe talks about moving off-grid in a digital sense: opting out of mainstream internet providers and building independent mesh networks or a peer-to-peer Web. Whatever the solution, making things more sustainable is a critical consideration for the next few decades.

Read The Internet‚Äôs Back-to-the-Land Movement.

The Rise and Demise of RSS

RSS is one of those wonderful Web technologies, meaning you can follow updates from anyone across the world. In simple terms, it‚Äôs a bit like tweets without Twitter. But depsite getting off to a good start, RSS has all but disappeared as people have moved to centralised silos like Twitter. The reason? Too many competing standards. The story of RSS teaches us that a better, more open Web will come from getting better at working together.

Read The Rise and Demise of RSS.

The Semantic Web identity crisis: in search of the trivialities that never were

In a similar vein to the story of RSS, Ruben Verborgh talks about the last two decades of research into the Semantic Web ‚Äì and how it hasn‚Äôt really changed the world much. The dream was big, the vision was crystal clear, but through lack of dogfooding the dream hasn‚Äôt been delivered. But if semantic technologies can be brough out of the research space and into the world of product development‚Ä¶who knows?

Read The Semantic Web identity crisis: in search of the trivialities that never were.

Data as institutional memory

Another excellent post about standards, from Adam, plumping for collaboratively developed standards as part of a system, not just a by-product of policy and legislation. ‚ÄòFix the plumbing by identifying the leaks‚Äô rang in my head for a couple of days after reading this, it‚Äôs a great analogy. Great stuff on designing data as infrastructure in the 21st century. (Adam running his mouth in the pub is something I enjoy being around, it produces gems like this.)

Read Data as institutional memory.

Why Data Is Never Raw

I don‚Äôt believe we should aim for data-driven futures because it renders human decisions as useless. Instead we should be data-informed, reading metrics and measures to inform our decisions. But it‚Äôs worth remembering that data is never raw: the schema by which you collect and read data goes some way to defining how you‚Äôll interpret it. In The New Atlantis, Nick Barrowman talks about the seductive myth of information free of human judgment.

Read Why Data Is Never Raw.

Unicorns, Ontologies and How the Mind Organizes the World

The world of structured data was a right headf**k when I first joined Porism. Since there‚Äôs much chatter about ontologies, taxonomies, registers and other aspects of semantic technologies at work now, I always send this article to anyone starting out. Who knew a story about Marco Polo would help frame it so well?!

Read Unicorns, Ontologies and How the Mind Organizes the World.

Just good stories

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not leaving this bar until we‚Äôve come up with such a great idea that I can‚Äôt sack you‚Äù

The story of how BBC iPlayer came about because of a drunken brainstorm as told by Tony Ageh, who was the project director for the thing. It‚Äôs funny and uplifting and wonderfully down-to-earth.

Read ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not leaving this bar until we‚Äôve come up with such a great idea that I can‚Äôt sack you‚Äù.

How William Gibson Keeps His Science Fiction Real

William Gibson invented the word ‚Äòcyberspace‚Äô and, along with it, the cyberpunk movement and everything that inspired. I grew up on The Matrix, Blade Runner, Johnny Mnemonic and the video game Deus Ex, so it‚Äôs pleasing to hear how the books that inspired those worlds ‚Äì beginning with Gibson‚Äôs debut Neuromancer ‚Äì came together.

Read How William Gibson Keeps His Science Fiction Real.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt all about drugs‚Äù

By talking to teenagers about the acid house movement of the 1980s, Jeremy Deller managed to explore the period and what it was really all about, without falling on the obvious answer of drugs. This is a good interview about his documentary, Everybody in the Place: an Incomplete History of Britain 1984‚Äì92, but you should definitely also watch the doc.

Read ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt all about drugs‚Äù.

The Brexit Warnings to Be Found in Sheep Grazing in a London Park

An overlapping of stories about the commons, Boudica, Hampstead Heath, and thoughts on Brexit back in September. (I mostly like it for the agricultural experiment and the archeology, but there‚Äôs something in there for politicos too.)

Read The Brexit Warnings to Be Found in Sheep Grazing in a London Park.

The real-life Ali G

Can‚Äôt remember why I came across this story about Tim Westwood but it‚Äôs absolutely cracking.

Read The real-life Ali G.

In 1968, computers got personal

The story of how ‚Äòthe mother of all demos‚Äô changed the world, moving computing from the research space to the commercial space. By helping people imagine a future in which everyone had a computer, we now do.

Read In 1968, computers got personal.

  1. If anyone has stratified the eras of government transformation, digital and beyond, please do let me know!¬†↩

item.title: Revivalist aesthetic: musical discoveries from 2019
item.description:
Last year I put together a playlist of music I‚Äôd loved or first listened to in 2018 and, genre-wise, it was relatively varied. Beats, jazz-funk, rock, club heaters, hip-hop and some essential bass music. This year‚Äôs list, however, is quite different to that. It‚Äôs a playlist of songs that are mostly all the same, to be honest.

2019 has been the year of the revivalist sound, with young producers harkening back to the days of 1990s rave with pumping modern tributes. The stand-out release for me has been Soundbwoy Killah‚Äôs Halcyon Daze, an LP ‚Äòsuffused‚Ä¶with the heady fug of rave memories and long nights in the dance‚Äô (as told by Bleep). They‚Äôre tunes that make you want to go raving again, even if your own halcyon days were 2006‚Äì2013, not the decade previous.

This playlist is packed with those kinds of tunes, it reeks of nostalgia.

In a way, it‚Äôs a mournful playlist. Going out these days isn‚Äôt like what it used to be (*cough* old man *cough*). In reviving the warehouse rave, clubs like Printworks have mass-marketed and stripped away the original appeal: underground folklore. It‚Äôs something Burial touches on in this interview with Wire magazine.

The UK was changing in a different direction, away from us. Maybe the feeling of the UK in clubs and stuff back then, it wasn‚Äôt as artificial, self-aware or created by the internet. It was more rumour, underground folklore. No mobile phones back then. Anyone could go into the night and they had to seek it out. Because you could see it in people, you could see it in their eyes. Those ravers were at the edge at their lives, they weren‚Äôt running ahead or falling behind, they were just right there and the tunes meant everything.

There was a time when I respected music in that way. These days I don‚Äôt give it enough dedication.

But then again, maybe it‚Äôs an optimistic playlist. The music I‚Äôve listened to and loved in 2019 seems to be sounds of a remembered era, and I‚Äôm really keen to go out and hear music again. I miss it: the swaying, the lights, the sweat, the laughs. So 41 tracks remembering all that has sparked my keenness to get dancing again.

Anyway, that‚Äôs enough blabbering. Here‚Äôs the playlist of tracks I discovered or loved in 2019. Listen on Spotify or Bandcamp through Buy Music Club.

item.title: Jam London 2019
item.description:
For the past few years I‚Äôve been going to Jam London, a product and design conference sharing the stories behind great products. It‚Äôs great to hear from product and design leaders from across the world, and I‚Äôve always learned a thing or two that I take back to my practice.

Here‚Äôs some rough notes I made on my phone during the talks, in case it‚Äôs helpful for others. The full line-up is here. The talks from Jamie Nicholson, Chelsea Bullock and Susana Lopes were best for me that day. Lots about navigating uncertainty, trust, empathy and failure.

Building with Stories

Jeff Gardner, Intercom

Stories the best way to organise people around a single idea. But why do we think we‚Äôre not capable of building stories? Here‚Äôs some tips on building better stories.

The type of story we‚Äôre telling is a business parable, driving someone‚Äôs behaviour to reach an outcome.

Good stories must have

  • a clear message
  • emotionally engaging
  • simple enough to be retold

A story is an idea virus, and good stories are contagious. It can be easy to make a story short, quicker to tell, retell and understand. Make stories short.

Focus on feelings, rather than details. How do you want the audience to feel?

Adapt to your audience. Comedians spend lots of time seeing jokes bomb to understand which will work. You need to try to be good. Saying ‚ÄòAnyway, it‚Äôs a long story‚Äô can help you understand whether anyone wants to hear it.

Make storytelling a practice, learn from what doesn‚Äôt work.

  • Start with the point
  • Set the scene, quickly
  • Use dialogue
  • Surprise!
  • Restate the point

Of all the animals, we‚Äôre the only ones that live in a dual reality: the world in front of us and the world in our heads.

Building trust with research teams

Chelsea Bullock, Mailchimp

Team dynamics are different when teams have trust between the members. New teams have lower trust; teams with trust move fast.

Worked on a project based on a VP‚Äôs idea with a team that had high trust. Tried to reframe the feature proposal but kept running into dead ends, it wasn‚Äôt going to work. They were asked how to do it, not whether to do it or not. Users didn‚Äôt fundamentally see the problem so the feature didn‚Äôt need it. High trust team only spiralled for a while and they quickly pivoted to saying ‚ÄòThis won‚Äôt work‚Äô and the company was grateful, saved money and time.

Mutual trust meant they could move from discovery to validation to learning very quickly.

How do you know if you‚Äôre working in a trust vacuum?

  • No one knows what you‚Äôre doing there
  • Deliverables feel safer than learnings
  • Doubts and suspicions about motivations and goals of team-mates

Trust gap can cause problems. Build empathy and trust to move forward together.

Stage Zero collaboration: or, where to start when you don‚Äôt know how to begin. First step in building trust between research partners is asking ‚ÄòWhat decision will these findings enable you to make?‚Äô Gives you

  • clarity of mission
  • buy-in on the stakes
  • alignment in prioritisation

Successfully answering that requires

  • curiosity
  • vulnerability & compassion
  • clear vision

Stories clarify our expectations of each other and acknowledge the value we all bring to the work. It energises teams and renews trust.

It‚Äôs really easy to keep our heads down and deliver, but we should turn these into collective stories. Show & tell often.

Trust over tools. Tools and frameworks are easy, but understanding and communication is most useful. Empathy. Ôøº Trust is better for team health. If there‚Äôs low trust, establish clarity of mission and get leadership involved.

How research inspires new products

Jamie Nicholson, Instagram

Design for and with people. Understand needs, desires and wants. Do research early, not after building.

Testing ideas and getting feedback is very important, but it‚Äôs easy to get lost and not move the needle (meet business objectives). What‚Äôs the problem you‚Äôre solving? How is that part of people‚Äôs lives?

Moved from ‚ÄòWhy do you use Instagram?‚Äô to ‚ÄòHow do you make friends?‚Äô

Looked at how the different features fit into making friendships. You might like an acquaintance‚Äôs photo, but you‚Äôll send a DM to a best friend.

  • Ask big questions. (How do they want to feel? Uncover behaviours and mental models, to see how this things sits in someone‚Äôs life.)
  • Get beneath the surface of what is said, people don‚Äôt know what they want. Go deep to find the magic they need.
  • Talk to extremes. Start at the edges and move inwards. Don‚Äôt go for average behaviours.

Personas are hard, you can‚Äôt design for the average with millions of users. Instead tell the stories of people you find that represent a broader group of people. It drives empathy in the team.

Agile for Everybody, Everybody Hates Agile

Matt LeMay, Sudden Compass

Agile is a completely made-up thing that 17 people dreamed up on a ski weekend, so ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Agile methods ask people to think and, frankly, that‚Äôs a hard sell. So be brave, get started and change the way you‚Äôre working until it works.

How to scale globally

Kaarel Kuddu, Transferwise

Launched in a country based on World Bank data. Didn‚Äôt work because they didn‚Äôt know their customers and how TransferWise fit into their lives.

Ran an experiment to see if people would choose currencies to send. Got some data, saw demand for currencies, launched those and tracked uptake. No correlation between demand and uptake because product experience wasn‚Äôt approached in the same way in different countries.

Failure

Maryam Mazraei, Autopsy

4 years of work ended in failure, which got her interested in taking lessons from failure. Survivor bias creates problems for people who follow the ‚Äòplaybook‚Äô.

Looking at the common components of failure help you to spot patterns.

Data from Crunchbase, OpenCorporates, Companies House, etc.

Keep pace, master product at BMW (100 years old)

Sabrina Rzepka, BMW

Working with cars different: no feature flags, no Build-Measure-Learn, no fail fast. Features have many dependencies.

  • Make a vision visible
  • Gain speed with a co-pilot
  • Focus on the essentials

You didn‚Äôt fail, your product did

Susana Lopes, Onfido

Behind pristine LinkedIn profiles are our bruised egos and failed projects. They‚Äôre lurking there and we never talk about our shadow careers.

Grew up with the ‚ÄòFailure is not an option‚Äô mantra but it turned her into a dictator. Worked at Huddle, they had quarterly commitments for sales people, things they‚Äôd deliver on time that didn‚Äôt exist yet. Made her think that success = shipping on time. Efficiency theatre.

By thinking that failure was not an option, she chose the easiest route to success - instead of actually delivering value to customers.

Fear of failure creates high pressure and clouded judgement. You need to release that pressure to succeed.

Swapped ‚ÄòFailure is not an option‚Äô for ‚ÄòFail fast, fail early‚Äô, de-risking aspects of the product.

Spoke to customers using web product on Android to collect problems, hoping to rebuild the Android app and convert those people. De-risked problem and value.

De-risked usability. De-risked feasibility. Kept shipping and growing, de-risking beforehand‚Ä¶until the numbers stalled. Value plateaued.

Didn‚Äôt validate that the problem existed for enough people, enough of the time. But blamed herself. Emotional resilience held her back.

But she didn‚Äôt fail, the product did. And she learned and can do better next time. Separate self-worth from product-worth, maybe by creating product success metrics and personal success metrics. Creates emotional distance by being product‚Äôs worst critic.

item.title: Reading List Picks of 2018
item.description:
It‚Äôs been a heck of a year. I got to fulfill a teenage dream and start working on an important and much-used website, which got me thinking about product management, people, work and the World Wide Web more than I did last year. Here‚Äôs a bunch of articles and blog posts that piqued my interest throughout 2018.

How to Build a Low-tech Website?

Low-tech Magazine looks at the sustainability of the modern world and its practices. They decided to practice what they preach by making their website run entirely on solar power, using web design techniques to reduce energy consumption and a self-built solar power bank to run it all ‚Äì no data centres and CDNs in sight. Though it occasionally goes offline when there‚Äôs not enough power, the article really got me thinking about the ‚Äòalways on‚Äô nature of the Web and how that‚Äôs quite wasteful.

Read How to Build a Low-tech Website?

The Bullshit Web

In a similar vein to Low-tech Magazine, Nick Heer wrote about the ballooning bullshit of data on the Web and the wastefulness of filling your 17MB/s internet connection with ads. It‚Äôs an essay on what the Web was meant to be, and what it has become; and how the Information Superhighway could benefit from those of us working on it to take more responsibility.

Read The Bullshit Web.

The Cognition Crisis

Waking up and checking your phone. Scrolling through Facebook while the telly‚Äôs on. Notifications causing drivers to kill people. Adam Gazzaley argues that ‚Äòour constant engagement with technology interferes with the pursuit of other behaviors critical for maintaining a healthy mind‚Äô, and it caused me to turn on Do Not Disturb when at work. We have natural animal minds that are being pushed to the edge by the environment we‚Äôve built around them.

Read The Cognition Crisis.

The principles that make me a better product manager

If there‚Äôs one thing that‚Äôs central to the practice of product management, it‚Äôs a set of principles one can call on in any situation. A good principle can keep everyone on course but also help point the way forward in unfamiliar waters. Ross Ferguson left us with seven principles before he was poached by the Canadians, and they‚Äôve really helped me in my first year at Government Digital Service.

Read The principles that make me a better product manager.

Thinking about SLOs

Working out how to maintain and operate a behemoth like GOV.UK was pretty daunting when I joined Platform Health. Adopting a Service Level Objective and thinking about how we manage technical solutions from a users-first perspective has been massively helpful. I‚Äôm really grateful that Emily posted this by Andrew Suffield ‚Äì one-time Site Reliability Engineer at Google ‚Äì and for all her work on spreading SLO thinking at GDS.

Read Thinking about SLOs.

Teams from Scratch ‚Äì Part 1: Psychological Safety

Building a culture where asking questions and admitting gaps in knowledge is OK can be hard, but this piece popped up serendipitously around the time I was doing a lot of thinking on team-building. It turned out that Alex worked at Unruly, an adtech company which shares our office building, and we‚Äôve been meeting for coffee ever since!

Read Teams from Scratch ‚Äì Part 1: Psychological Safety.

How did privacy come to be enshrined as a human right?

In this year of our Lord, 2018, when the General Data Protection Regulation was enshrined in law, no doubt many of us were thinking Why on earth are we going through all this pain? Preparing for GDPR was a huge undertaking, and despite the boring spreadsheets and confusing issues around compliance, I think it‚Äôs largely a Good Thing. This series by Projects by IF traces the history of our right to privacy and the role of regulation.

Read How did privacy come to be enshrined as a human right?.

Microdosing Isn‚Äôt a Shortcut to Professional Success

Being employed in Tech, with working weeks called ‚Äòsprints‚Äô, can often feel like you‚Äôre actually running a race, and open plan offices can dwindle your focus. Some people turn to microdosing ‚Äì taking small amounts of psychoactive drugs ‚Äì to find a balance, but Erica Avey argues that perhaps we should change the way we work, not our biology. This article applies to coffee as much as it does to LSD, in my eyes.

Read Microdosing Isn‚Äôt a Shortcut to Professional Success.

Weeknotes styles

This year I started writing weeknotes, a weekly reflection on my working week, and I‚Äôve found the practice really beneficial. It‚Äôs like a personal retrospective, giving you a chance to package up the week and move on, making improvements. I recommend it to a lot of people I meet, and Sam wrote this piece on the different styles the Web of Weeknotes community uses.

Read Weeknotes styles.

This isn‚Äôt for everyone

What surprised me most when I joined GDS was that many of our products didn‚Äôt have defined user personas. Nor did we say who we wouldn‚Äôt build things for. Not all users are equal. The mindset of building for everyone is helpful in not excluding certain groups, but it can widen the scope of a product too much. The Parliament Data team, and Michael in particular, have been good in acknowledging that.

Read This isn‚Äôt for everyone.

Democratic technical debt

Digital government has surged forth leaving improved services in its wake. But how much of the enhancements are only surface-deep? ‚ÄòIf you don‚Äôt consider what the long term impact of how you build something is, you‚Äôre accruing democratic technical debt,‚Äô author Alex Blandford says. While also positing that terrific idea, Alex also points out that, well, government has been a bit shit at providing the research it has conducted. A few blog posts ain‚Äôt enough.

Read Democratic technical debt.

Building personal resilience (or how to avoid burnout)

This year has been hectic, and it‚Äôs possible for work to become all-consuming if you‚Äôre not careful. What helped me avoid that was to draw a line between my professional and personal lives: I used weeknotes to package up the week, and I used personal time to replenish my mind and soul. Pippa takes a great perspective on how to do that in this post.

Read Building personal resilience (or how to avoid burnout).

Targeted Advertising Is Ruining the Internet and Breaking the World, and We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites

In March, I stopped using Facebook to see whether I‚Äôd miss it. It wasn‚Äôt a problem at all, in fact there‚Äôs not a single feature I longed for, so I deleted my account. That‚Äôs mostly been driven by their abysmal record for privacy in recent months and their involvement in the Cambridge Analytica atrocity. I‚Äôve read countless articles on Facebook this year, but these two stand out. One shows us how advertising has been a misplaced driver for social media firms, and the other reminds us how the Web worked before the 2.0 giants took over.

Read Targeted Advertising Is Ruining the Internet and Breaking the World and We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites.

This is how we work‚Ä¶give or take

Matt Jukes is a legend of the civic tech space, a dynamo of humble magnificence with a Bristol accent ‚Äì an honest, friendly, earnest kind of bloke. So of course he wrote an open piece on how he works, which caused people from all across the public sector (and others) to write one too. It‚Äôs a fascinating to read.

Read This is how we work‚Ä¶give or take.

Empowered Product Teams

This blog post covers much of Marty Cagan‚Äôs talk when he visited us in September. It‚Äôs a long read but it‚Äôs absolutely essential for organisations scaling up, past the startup mindset. It reminds us that qualities of leadership can be better than management, and that great teams are full of ordinary people.

Read Empowered Product Teams.

item.title: This is how I work‚Ä¶give or take
item.description:
Dan wanted to see how I work, so here‚Äôs what I do, based on Jukesie‚Äôs rip-off of the Lifehacker ‚ÄòHow I Work‚Äô series. Other public service folk have written about how they work too.

Location: London, UK.
Current gig: Associate product manager, Government Digital Service.
Current mobile device: Samsung J5 for work, iPhone 8 for percy.
Current computer: MacBook Air 13‚Äù for work. Mac Mini at home. Some hobby Raspberry Pis and a PC too.
One word that best describes how you work: Metered.

First of all, tell us a little about your background and how you got to where you are today

Liked books and computers growing up. Spent a huge portion of my teenage years in my bedroom, tinkering on the Web or with computers. But I also enjoyed writing stories. Aged 16, I decided to focus on my Literature studies instead of Information Technology. It seemed to have‚Ä¶more prestige.

Did my A-levels, went to Bath Spa Uni to study Creative Writing. Bought a Mac to stop me playing video games. It worked, and I had a lot of fun. The course was excellent with great teachers ‚Äì check out some of the authors who‚Äôve also studied at Bath Spa ‚Äì and I had my sights set on a career in publishing.

Graduated. Spent the next year continuing cheffing, then quit to get some work experience and make the most of my degree. Spent two weeks as a managing editorial assistant at Vintage Publishing (part of Random House) and was asked back for another week. A few months later, there‚Äôs an open position as an editorial assistant and they ask me to apply. Incredibly, I get it and dive into the literary publishing world.

Do that for 9 months. Move on to Jonathan Cape, attend a Booker Prize ceremony in my first week. It‚Äôs quite glitzy, maybe too glitzy, especially for a working class boy from Wolverhampton. I get the chance to work with some of the most eminent, prolific literary authors in the world. They even let me commission a book of short stories. But I feel massively out of my depth and haven‚Äôt been to Oxbridge, like most others at my level. Self-doubt sets in. Work is naught but toil. I grow tired of the sausage factory. I quit.

And so I have a breakdown.

The clouds pass after 6 months and I get a job at NOW TV, which was just starting out. See Agile and software development in action. Turns out that‚Äôs quite glitzy too, except I didn‚Äôt know that at school. IT is kind of cool now. Hmm, maybe I could do tech after all. After some time in Operations, they initiate a TUPE process for an entire department and I need to find other work. Porism has an opening for someone.

First, I focus on increasing engagement and use of LG Inform Plus, then get the chance to redesign and launch a new version of eCasework. We spent a year on that before it went live. Take-up wasn‚Äôt good. I wrestled with marketing techniques, sales, developing some features and trying to talk to the few users we had. Wasn‚Äôt really sure what I was doing. It was‚Ä¶enjoyable, but also like banging my head against a brick wall. Repeatedly. Every day. Because I‚Äôm leading myself blind. (However, I also learn some cool stuff about open data, local government and generally learn tons from Mike.)

Explaining my anguish to a friend, he suggests that I‚Äôm kind of doing product management. I read a few blogs, try out the techniques, and they work. Hmm, maybe I could do tech after all. Attending the product management course at General Assembly gives me new skills. We start to grow eCasework and its user base. We develop features that people love. But I‚Äôm a bit hungry for more.

Apply for a job working on GOV.UK. They offer it to me. I‚Äôm overjoyed.

And now I‚Äôm just really, really happy. I‚Äôm at home. I‚Äôm back in my bedroom, tinkering on the Web and with computers, on a piece of the national infrastructure.

Take us through a recent workday

There‚Äôs a T-shaped structure to my week which I try to stick to. Mornings are for product thinking, writing cards or catching up on important emails, except on Wednesdays when I‚Äôll meet Alex for coffee. Then it‚Äôs a catch-up with Delivery Manager and Tech Lead, followed by stand-up with the team.

On Tuesdays and Wednesdays, the rest of the day is either meetings, team ceremonies or community meet-ups with other product managers.

Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays are a bit lighter: product thinking, analysing data and trends, and chats with other specialists, often dappled with the odd meeting here and there.

The details of what actually happens can be found in my weeknotes.

What apps, gadgets or tools can‚Äôt you live without?

Slack Reminders, my philosopher‚Äôs stone at work. With simple commands, I can remind myself or a colleague to do something. Need I say more? Since I have the app on my iPhone too, I can capture those work-related thoughts that spring up in the shower, at dinner or when I‚Äôm on holiday. It gets things out of my head, and only brings them back when needed.

Recently I‚Äôve been using Pocket a fair amount to save blogs to read. Medium‚Äôs Reading List also comes in handy, but I‚Äôm trying to move away from the platform.

But Twitter, too. It‚Äôs the app I use most. To both fill time productively and waste it. My Social Summary is great for catching up on Twitter without needing to scroll through Twitter. It looks for the most engaging tweets from lists you‚Äôve built and sends you a daily digest. Definitely worth ¬£3 a month.

I‚Äôve really taken to Post-it notes as a to-do list. I tried Trello but you‚Äôre not always able to add cards in meetings or ceremonies. Post-its are always at hand in GDS, so I can quickly capture sudden thoughts.

Here‚Äôs some stuff I‚Äôve used at work before.

What‚Äôs your best shortcut or life hack?

If you have to do something three times, automate it. If you can‚Äôt automate it, find a way to reduce the toil. You‚Äôll immediately create more time to spend on things that really need it.

Take us through an interesting, unusual, or finicky process you have in place at work

If you forget your work pass, you can‚Äôt get through many of the (mostly glass) doors. You end up staring forlornly at the people on the other side, who don‚Äôt know whether to let you in sans ID. Sometimes several people walk past before you‚Äôre permitted to exit your dimension of uselessness.

I haven‚Äôt worked out how to capitalise on this yet. It‚Äôs a bit like a cigarette break.

How do you keep track of what you have to do?

Like I said earlier, Slack Reminders and Post-it notes.

What‚Äôs your favourite side project?

I‚Äôm currently playing with Jekyll to refresh my website and move blog posts away from Medium. But I‚Äôm also running out of kimchi so will have to make some more of that soon.

What are you currently reading, or what do you recommend to read?

I‚Äôm reading Throwing Rocks at the Google Bus by Douglas Rushkoff for non-fiction, and Memoirs of Hadrian by Marguerite Yourcenar for fiction.

Who else would you like to see answer these questions?

Mike, Ellie, Alex, John, Emily and Femke.

What‚Äôs the best advice you‚Äôve ever received?

‚ÄòYou can do whatever you want in life, as long as you don‚Äôt hurt anyone.‚Äô Oh, and: ‚ÄòWork is just a way to pay the bills, but it helps if you enjoy it.‚Äô Both from my dad.
